The unceasing skirmish-fire encreased to a long
clattering sound. With it was mingled faraway cheering. A battery spoke.
Directly, Fleming the youthcould see the skirmishers running.
They were pursued by the sound of musketry fire. After a time,
the hot dangerous flashes of the rifles were visible. Smoke-clouds
went slowly and insolently across the fields, like observant
phantoms. The din became crescendo like the roar of an
oncoming train.
A brigade ahead of them and on the right went into
